text: Connect a PxrLayer or PxrLayerMixer node here to apply one or more layers.  Note that when a lobe is enabled (e.g. enableDiffuse) in PxrLayer, those parameters for that lobe in PxrLayer will replace and override the same parameters for that lobe in PxrSurface.
Diffuse falloff exponent. This is for Lambertian model only, i.e. when diffuse roughness is 0.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this diffuse lobe.
If on, the back side will use the regular Diffuse Color. Turn it off to enable a specific Back Color field.
Artistic mode uses Face and Edge Color and Fresnel Exponent. Physical mode uses Refractive Index and Extinction Coefficient as in most other Bxdfs.
Specular Fresnel curve exponent.  5.0 is a good default.  This is normaly unchanged.  If changed, this affects the face and edge falloff.

Select a specular model.  Both are competitively good models. If you need to match the look to some other Bxdf, such as the Disney bsdf, use Ggx because most Bxdfs are hard-coded to use Ggx.  Beckmann highlights are relatively sharp, while Ggx highlights have softer falloff. There is no set rule, pick the model which delivers the targeted visual result you are after.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this specular lobe.
Artistic mode uses Face and Edge Color and Fresnel Exponent. Physical mode uses Refractive Index and Extinction Coefficient as in most other Bxdfs.
Specular Fresnel curve exponent.  5.0 is a good default.  This is normaly unchanged.  If changed, this affects the face and edge falloff.

Select a specular model.  Both are competitively good models. If you need to match the look to some other Bxdf, such as the Disney bsdf, use Ggx because most Bxdfs are hard-coded to use Ggx.  Beckmann highlights are relatively sharp, while Ggx highlights have softer falloff. There is no set rule, pick the model which delivers the targeted visual result you are after.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this specular lobe.
Artistic mode uses Face and Edge Color and Fresnel Exponent. Physical mode uses Refractive Index and offers some absorption properties.
Clearcoat Fresnel curve exponent.  5.0 is a good default.  This is normaly unchanged.  If changed, this affects the face and edge falloff.

Select a specular model.  Both are competitively good models. If you need to match the look to an existing Bxdf, such as the Disney bsdf, use Ggx because most Bxdfs are hard-coded to use Ggx.  Beckmann highlights are relatively shar, while Ggx highlights have softer falloff. There is no set rule, pick the model which delivers the targeted visual result you are after.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this clearcoat lobe.

When this is set to > 0.0, it applies energy compensation to the diffuse and subsurface illumination. This is a view dependent fresnel energy compensation.  This effect is visible when we have a low specular face color and high edge color. A value of 1.0 attempts to fully balance those illuminations by darkening them against the specular and rough specular illumination responses. Specular and Rough Specular roughness are also taken into account. The effect fades off as specular face or edge color approaches 1.0.

When clearcoat energy compensation is set to > 0.0, it applies energy compensation to all the lobes other than the clearcoat itself. We assume clearcoat is the layer above diffuse, subsurface, and specular. This is a view dependent fresnel energy compensation.  This effect is visible when we have a low clearcoat face color and high edge color. A value of 1.0 attempts to fully balance those illums by darkening them against the clearcoat illumination response. Clearcoat roughness is also taken into account.  The effect fades off as clearcoat face or edge color approaches 1.0.
Iridescence fresnel curve exponent.  5.0 is a good default.  This is normally unchanged.  If changed, this affects the face and edge falloff.

In Artistic mode, we just set 2 colors. Depending on the iridescence scale factor, we will see N number of 'rainbows'. In Physical mode, we pass the thickness of your thin film in nanometer. The iridescence effect happens when the physical thickness is close to the visible spectrum. You can start around 800nm and increase the value to see the effect.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
Falloff speed from Primary Color to Secondary Color.  Bigger number falloffs slower.
Falloff Scale.  This sets how many times the 'rainbows' repeat.
Flip the hue wheel direction between primary and secondary colors. By default, the hue wheel direction is counter clockwise.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this iridescence lobe.
If this is set, this normal will be used for the fuzz illumination instead of the bump normal set in the Globals.

Subsurface profile types. Jensen’s dipole and d'Eon’s better dipole profiles model subsurface diffusion, i.e. subsurface scattering after many bounces of scattering.  Burley’s normalized profile models both diffusion and single-scattering.  Path traced implements brute-force Monte Carlo scattering.

Controls the depth of light bleed in the subsurface medium. Has the effect of increasing the distance light travels in the medium while preserving fine detail, compared to increasing the Mean Free Path.
Blends a diffuse component into the subsurface calculation. Useful on objects with very sharp edges where dark artifacts can be seen.
If the geometry has self-intersections, enabling this option will track the surfaces so that only the outer-most ones are active for subsurface light transport.
When enabled, light will only exit the surface at perpendicular angles to the surface, and oblique paths are internally reflected. This can help avoid excessive brightness in curved areas.

Switch the subsurface computation to a diffuse computation if the dmfp is smaller than the ray footprint.  This gives a useful speed-up for frontlit objects, but gives incorrect results for thin backlit objects where the subsurface scattering will traverse the object whereas diffuse will not.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this subsurface lobe.
Whether subsurface respects surfaces on the otherside.
'Off' - It will ignore surfaces on the other side completely. This is useful to make objects appear thicker than they are.
'On' - Normal mode, where the diffusion happens between the front and the first surface behind it.
'Off' - Simply trace out of the object (default)

'LastHit' - Ignore internal geometry and jump to the last surface * 'AllHits' - Scatter (collect light) on all hits as the ray leaves the object. This can bring additional brightness, at the cost of additional noise.
Maximum number of hits to test in all hits mode.

Controls how strongly normals are considered in the subsurface computation. For diffusion sss (subsurfaceTypes 0–4), the followTopology parameter reduces sss from one side to another in concave regions such as crevasses and wrinkles. For path-traced sss (subsurfaceTypes 5–6), the followTopology parameter reduces sss paths being blocked by backsides behind a surface, but also reduces sss from one side to another in convex regions such as ridges and ears.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this single scatter lobe.
Whether single scatter respects surfaces on the otherside.
'Off' - It will ignore surfaces on the other side completely. This is useful to make objects apear thicker than they are.
'On' - Normal mode, where the scattering happens between the front and the first surface behind it.
'Off' - Simply trace out of the object (default)

'LastHit' - Ignore internal geometry and jump to the last surface * 'AllHits' - Scatter (collect light) on all hits as the ray leaves the object. This can bring additional brightness, at the cost of additional noise.
Maximum number of hits to test in all hits mode.
Control the continuation ray mode for direct gain.
'FirstHit' - Simply trace to the next surface (this is tied to considerBackside)

'LastHit' - Ignore internal geometry and jump to the last surface * 'AllHits' - Scatter (collect light) on all hits as the ray leaves the object. This can bring additional brightness, at the cost of additional noise.
A tint applied to illumination before being scattered by subsurface or single scatter.
Diffuse roughness (OrenNayar model) to be applied for subsurface or single scatter.

Subsurface and single scatter unit length.  It is a multiplier on Mean Free Path Distance.  Mean Free Path Distance is often measured in millimeters.  If the scene is modeled in some other scale, Unit Length should be set accordingly.  The default value of 0.1 is appropriate for scenes modeled in centimeters and Mean Free Path Distance measured in millimeters.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, enables the use of manifold exploration algorithms (such as manifold walk and caustic connection strategies) on this surface.
If on, correctly split energy according to IOR between reflection and refraction, but do not bend the ray in refraction (simulating a double pane of glass with a single pane).
If on, forces the fresnel IOR weighting to be off (which has the side-effect of turning reflection off). This is sometimes desirable for extracting a pure refraction distortion mask for compositing.
If on, even if the integrator has Accum Opacity on (where the intention is to generate a partial alpha from refraction for compositing), the alpha will be locally forced to 1.0 after refraction.
Color of the particles in the volume.
Extinction coefficient that controls how light is absorbed as it travels through the volume. Higher values will block more light.
Controls the directionality of the scattering (1: forward, -1: backward, 0:isotropic).
Controls the secondary directionality of the scattering (1: forward, -1: backward, 0:isotropic).
Glow coefficient that controls how much light is emitted from the volume.
If enable, the interior volume can be overlapped with other volumes to create combined effects.
Glow gain.  This is a multiplier for the glow.
Controls the glow (incandescence) of the material.
Shadow Bump Terminator. Hide the abrupt shadow terminator line when strong bump or normal maps are used.
Shadow computation mode. 'Shade and shadow color' mode evaluates the shader for the opacity color for computing the shadow color.

Connect a mask function here to apply a cutout pattern to your object.  Presence is defined as a binary (0 or 1) function that can take on continuous values to antialias the shape.  Useful for modeling leaves and other thin, complex shapes.
If on, allows the manifold exploration algorithm to start on this surface.

The integrator parameter Specular Curvature Filter increases roughness after hitting curved and or partially rough objects.  This clamp can be used to limit the effect of the integrator parameter for particular surfaces.
User color provided to the bxdf to be stored in the user lobe 4.
Utility patterns are evaluated but their results are not used by the bxdf. This is where input AOV is connected.
